John Travilla Ramsay

Jack Ramsay pictured in 1977, the year the Portland Trail Blazers won the NBA championship.

Coaching career highlights:

  • Postwar yearly years: Coached in high school and minor league.
  • 1955: Hired as head coach of St Joseph college, who went 23-6 to win their first Big 5 championship.
  • 1963: Earned doctorate degree in education, leading to him being commonly known as 'Dr. Jack'.
  • 1966: Diagnosed with edema and left college coaching per his doctors recommendation. Finishing with a career record of 234-72, he held the record of most winningest coach in St. Joseph's history until 2005.
  • 1967: Hired as the general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers. In his first season, the 76ers won the NBA title averaging 125 points per game thanks to their star Wilt Chamberlain.
  • 1968: Hired as head coach of the 76ers, they finished with a record of 55-27 and led the NBA in scoring (119 ppg) as a result of Ramsay's style of aggressive pressing defense.
  • 1972: Left the 76ers after they missed the playoffs for the first time in team history.
  • 1972: Hired as the head coach of the Buffalo Braves. In his second year with the team, his coaching style again led his team to finish first among scoring (111.6 ppg).
  • 1975: Parts ways with the Braves as the team was sold and moved to San Diego. In four seasons he took the team to three playoff berths and finished with a record of 158-170.
  • 1976: Hired as head coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, who in their 6 year history had never made the playoffs. They had a very young team led by stars Bill Walton, and Maurice Lucas.
  • 1977: Led the Blazers to their first and only NBA title. He continued to coach the team until 1986 but never achieved the same level of success after their star Bill Walton battled constant foot injuries.
  • 1978: Coached the Western Conference team as part of the All-Star Game.
  • 1986: Hired as head coach of the Indiana Pacers and lead them to their second winning record in team history.
  • 1989: Resigned as Pacers coach after a 0-7 start.
  • 1992: Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame.
  • 1993: The Portland Trail Blazers retired number 77 in Ramsay's honor to recognize the 1977 championship.
  • 1996: Voted one of the 10 greatest coaches in NBA history.
  • 2014: At the age of 89, Ramsay died of cancer in his sleep the night of April 28.

You can read more about this Portland icon on his Wikipedia entry.
